awd_titl_txt: REU Site:Research Experience for Undergraduates at the Temple Materials Institute (TMI)
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description: It is critical in our society to expand research opportunities to students in academic institutions where research and advanced interdisciplinary studies do not exist. The broader impact of this project is to create a pipeline of such students. By interfacing the REU students with TUteach mentors (pre-service STEM teacher candidates) and summer high school students (who will also be at Temple University during the summer), the project will instill a culture where students at any level can help and inspire other students, and learn how to explain complex topics/problems at a more easily understood level. The students participating in this project will be working on problems that are of fundamental scientific and technological interest, and will advance the state of knowledge in areas such as energy storage and conversion, plasmonics and nanomaterials. Faculty mentors have been selected based on their significant contribution to these fields, as partially measured by their citation impact. 

Technical Description: The objectives of the project are to immerse 10 undergraduate students each summer in an exciting and broad range of materials research in areas that will have enormous societal and environmental impacts. The project will interest the students in pursuing careers in areas such as energy storage, nanomaterials and catalysis. The students targeted for recruitment are those from two year undergraduate institutions who will eventually pursue 4 year degrees, but who will otherwise be at a big disadvantage compared with their peers at research universities. The project will aim to show the students that research or teaching in STEM fields is an interesting and rewarding career path for them, and that they can contribute to developing a future with a cleaner environment, and one that minimizes energy consumption. The project will be interdisciplinary, combining faculty from the Departments of Chemistry, Physics and Engineering. In addition, the project will form cohorts (along with other undergraduate summer students at Temple) of students who will work together on interdisciplinary project that integrate experimental and theory/modeling research. This will not only necessitate the development of communication skills, but is also the way in which many complex problems must be investigated. The activities for the students are designed to (i) give broad overviews of selected topics, e.g. 'Why must batteries be improved?', 'What is an oxygen evolution catalyst?', 'What are molecular simulations?' (via brown bag lunches); (ii) introduce students to the ethics and language of science, i.e. how to write papers and give presentations (via a weekly structured course); (iii) show what information from state-of-the-art instruments can provide (via Temple Materials Institute workshop); (iv) give the students practice and confidence in presenting their own research and also in asking questions to each other and faculty members (via presentations of their research). All activities are timely, as many deal with today's common energy challenges.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) at Temple Materials Institute (TMI) immersed three cohorts of undergraduate students in an exciting and broad range of materials research over three summers at Temple University. Participating students included underrepresented minorities (URMs) and first-generation college students recruited from community colleges, historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs), Minority Serving Institutions (MSIs), and small liberal arts colleges with limited resources for research. 

Each research participant completed ten weeks of interdisciplinary materials research, academic mentoring, career exploration, cohort-building social events, and near-peer activities.  

Our project outcomes include descriptive and quantitative factors related to student engagement in undergraduate research. 

Understanding Materials Science

Our recruitment work required direct and intentional efforts to help students in small liberal arts colleges, HBCUs, and MSIs understand the interdisciplinary nature of material science and the contributions made by their STEM discipline in designing and characterizing materials. We visited schools within 100 miles of our institutions to reach our target population (URM/underserved). When COVID limited the in-person visits, we shifted to virtual meetings that were less effective. Still, significant outreach informing students on materials science as an area of study happened each year of the project.  

Participant Demographics

Participants included 21 females and 10 males, of which 61% were African American, 6% were Asian, 6% were Caucasian, 23% were Hispanic, and 3% were North African/Middle Eastern. Additionally, 48% were first-generation college students. 

In the Lab

Students worked with faculty mentors on projects that spanned computational and experimental applications. Over three years, students studied the viscosity reduction of biofluids/fuels utilizing electric and magnetic fields, superconducting and insulating thin films, ferritin catalysis, nanoparticles for environmental remediation and catalysis, spectral analysis of gold surfaces, biomedical and dental materials, and photoluminescent sensors. The students shared data and progress weekly, informing the group as a whole on the interdisciplinary nature of material science while underscoring their contributions to the larger project's success.

Beyond the Lab

Students studied beyond the lab and contributed to STEM education outreach. Our research fellows attended workshops providing laboratory skills well beyond their disciplinary curriculum. For many students, this was their first research and first project experience. Our mentor training was valuable in encouraging successful project outcomes from our research students. Students were able to explore careers and post-baccalaureate education options and began to understand work/life balance from our career development program. Additionally, our research fellows had a meal w/ the dean. Discussions with the Dean focused on research failures and successes, advice, encouragement, and friendly exchanges of experiences on both sides.

Our near-peer symposium allowed our research fellows the opportunity to develop communication skills and prepare for our culminating research day events. More significantly, our fellows shared their experiences and explained the research process and their results to over 250 high school students, primarily low-income and URM, through the grant period. 

The high school students were highly engaged. A faculty presentation focusing on research opportunities in college choice and research motivating academic success closed this symposium for high school students. The engagement of our research fellows with students only 2-3 years younger benefited both sides.

Research Products

Ten former NSF-REU researchers presented their summer research at conferences, including ACS, ERN, and EAS. Three former NSF-REU researchers presented their summer research in the form of a poster presentation conference at the 2021 Temple University College of Science and Technology Research Symposium.

Culminating Event

A goal of our project was that all the research fellows would fully integrate into Temple University labs working with other undergraduate research students while being guided by graduate students, postdocs, and faculty mentors. A culminating symposium was held at Temple University each summer. Research participants presented their work to colleagues, STEM faculty, postdocs, undergraduate and graduate students, staff, and high school students participating in a summer STEM program. This event was a celebration of success and accomplishment.

Modified by: Susan A Jansen Varnum
